On the sensitivity of pose estimation neural networks: rotation parameterizations, Lipschitz constants, and provable bounds

Trevor Avant trevoravant@gmail.com â€ƒâ€ƒ Kristi A. Morgansen morgansn@uw.edu Department of Aeronautics and Astronautics, University of Washington, Seattle, WA 98195-2400, United States
Abstract

In this paper, we approach the task of determining sensitivity bounds for pose estimation neural networks. This task is particularly challenging as it requires characterizing the sensitivity of 3D rotations. We develop a sensitivity measure that describes the maximum rotational change in a networkâ€™s output with respect to a Euclidean change in its input. We show that this measure is a type of Lipschitz constant, and that it is bounded by the product of a networkâ€™s Euclidean Lipschitz constant and an intrinsic property of a rotation parameterization which we call the â€œdistance ratio constantâ€. We derive the distance ratio constant for several rotation parameterizations, and then discuss why the structure of most of these parameterizations makes it difficult to construct a pose estimation network with provable sensitivity bounds. However, we show that sensitivity bounds can be computed for networks which parameterize rotation using unconstrained exponential coordinates. We then construct and train such a network and compute sensitivity bounds for it.

1 Introduction

In the past few years, deep neural networks have achieved remarkable success at the task of object pose estimation [1, 2, 3, 4]. However, a major downside of deep learning-based methods is that deep neural networks are not well-understood mathematically and lack provable performance guarantees. This lack of theoretical understanding is problematic as pose estimation networks are often intended to be applied to real-world applications which require safe and reliable operation. Therefore, it is necessary to develop better tools to analyze pose estimation networks in order to use them in the real world.

One significant disadvantage of deep neural networks is that they are often highly sensitive, and small changes in a networkâ€™s input can result in huge changes in its output [5]. One of the primary tools for analyzing neural network sensitivity is the Lipschitz constant, which measures the maximum distance between two outputs of a function with respect to the distance between the two corresponding inputs, taken over all admissible pairs of inputs. Although exact computation of a networkâ€™s Lipschitz constant is too formidable for all but very small networks [6], an upper bound can be computed instead. Other work has also considered estimating Lipschitz constants [7, 8, 9, 10], as well as specifically analyzing the sensitivity of classification networks (often with regard to adversarial examples) [11, 12, 13, 14].

While sensitivity analysis of general neural networks and of classification neural networks are active areas of research, to the best of our knowledge, the sensitivity of pose estimation neural networks has not yet been studied. This task is particularly challenging as sensitivity must be considered using a measure of rotational distance rather than a norm-based metric such as the Euclidean distance. As such, we measure network sensitivity as the maximum rotational distance between two outputs of a network with respect to the Euclidean distance between the two corresponding inputs. We show that this measure is a type of Lipschitz constant, and that it is bounded by the product of two values: the networkâ€™s Euclidean Lipschitz constant, and a measure we call the â€œdistance ratio constantâ€ which is the maximum ratio of the rotational and Euclidean distances between all pairs of rotation parameters.

Analyzing the sensitivity of a pose estimation network will depend on which specific rotation parameterization is used. A variety of rotation parameterizations have been used in the literature, with some examples shown in Figure 1. In this paper we consider five types of rotation parameterizations: exponential coordinates, unconstrained exponential coordinates, quaternions, unconstrained quaternions, and 2D projection parameterizations. We show how the structure of most of these parameterizations raise difficulties in constructing a pose estimation network with provable rotational sensitivity bounds. However, we demonstrate that such bounds can be determined for networks which parameterize rotation using unconstrained exponential coordinates. We then construct such a network and calculate rotational sensitivity bounds for it.

The remainder of this paper is organized as follows. In Section 2, we discuss mathematical properties of 3D rotations and pose. In Section 3, we discuss Lipschitz constants, construct a Lipschitz constant that measures the sensitivity of a pose estimation neural network and derive a bound on it. We derive the distance ratio constant for exponential coordinates and quaternions, respectively, in Sections 4 and 5. In Section 6, we summarize our findings from the previous sections and discuss their implications in creating a pose estimation neural network with provable bounds. We then go on to construct a pose estimation neural network which outputs rotation in the form of unconstrained exponential coordinates, and calculate sensitivity bounds for the network. Finally, we discuss areas of future work and provide concluding remarks in Section 7.

2 Pose and 3D rotations

In this section, we will provide background information on pose and 3D rotations of a rigid objects, and we will define a distance measure between 3D rotations.

2.1 Pose and 3D rotations

The pose of a rigid object is defined as its position and orientation. The set of all 3D positions and orientations is topologically characterized by SE(3), the â€œspecial Euclidean groupâ€ in three dimensional Euclidean space. Pose is often parameterized by treating position and rotation separately, in which case position can be described by a 3D vector, and rotation can be described by a rotation parameterization such as exponential coordinates or quaternions. In other representations of pose, such as 2D projected points, position and rotation are coupled.

The set of all rotations about the origin in three-dimensional Euclidean space is termed the special orthogonal group in three dimensions, SO(3). Each element of SO(3) can be described by an orthogonal 3Ã—3333{\times}3 matrix with determinant equal to one:

SO(3)={ğ‘âˆˆâ„3Ã—3|ğ‘Tâ€‹ğ‘=ğˆ,detâ€‹(ğ‘)=1}SO(3)conditional-setğ‘superscriptâ„33formulae-sequencesuperscriptğ‘ğ‘‡ğ‘ğˆdetğ‘1\textrm{SO(3)}=\{\mathbf{R}\in\mathbb{R}^{3\times 3}~{}~{}|~{}~{}\mathbf{R}^{T}\mathbf{R}=\mathbf{I},~{}~{}\textrm{det}(\mathbf{R})=1\} (1)

where detâ€‹(â‹…)detâ‹…\textrm{det}(\cdot) denotes the determinant operation, and ğˆâˆˆâ„3Ã—3ğˆsuperscriptâ„33\mathbf{I}\in\mathbb{R}^{3\times 3} denotes the identity matrix.

There are many different parameterizations of the group of 3D rotations, including quaternions, exponential coordinates, and Euler angles. In this paper, we will use the symbol ğ’«âŠ†â„mğ’«superscriptâ„ğ‘š\mathcal{P}\subseteq\mathbb{R}^{m} to denote a set of rotation parameters, and the symbol ğ©âˆˆğ’«ğ©ğ’«\mathbf{p}\in\mathcal{P} to denote a particular parameter in that set. The symbols ğ’«ğ’«\mathcal{P} and ğ©ğ©\mathbf{p} are generic in that they do not correspond to any specific parameterization, and they will be replaced with specific symbols when considering a specific rotation parameterization. For example, when considering quaternions, ğ’«ğ’«\mathcal{P} will be replaced with ğ’®3âŠ‚â„4superscriptğ’®3superscriptâ„4\mathcal{S}^{3}\subset\mathbb{R}^{4} (see (44)), and ğ©ğ©\mathbf{p} will be replaced with ğªâˆˆâ„4ğªsuperscriptâ„4\mathbf{q}\in\mathbb{R}^{4}.

2.2 Rotational distance

We now consider the task of quantifying the â€œdistanceâ€ between two 3D rotations. As the set of 3D rotations is structured as a Riemannian manifold, Euclidean distance cannot be used to properly measure distance for rotations. A proper measure of rotational distance is the angle of direct rotation between two 3D rotations. This measure provides a consistent measure of rotational distance, can be applied to any rotation parameterization, and is intuitive as it corresponds to an angle of rotation.

Definition 1.

The rotational distance between two 3D rotations is the angle of direct rotation between the two rotations using an axis-angle representation. Letting ğ’«ğ’«\mathcal{P} denote a set of rotation parameters, we denote the rotational distance function as dist:ğ’«Ã—ğ’«â†’[0,Ï€]:distâ†’ğ’«ğ’«0ğœ‹\mathrm{dist}:\mathcal{P}\times\mathcal{P}\rightarrow[0,\pi].

The function distâ€‹(â‹…,â‹…)distâ‹…â‹…\mathrm{dist}(\cdot,\cdot) is overloaded notation as its explicit expression will depend on which rotation parameterization is being considering. For example, the rotational distance between two rotation matrices ğ‘1,ğ‘2âˆˆâ„3Ã—3subscriptğ‘1subscriptğ‘2superscriptâ„33\mathbf{R}_{1},\mathbf{R}_{2}\in\mathbb{R}^{3\times 3} is given by the following equation:

distâ€‹(ğ‘1,ğ‘2)distsubscriptğ‘1subscriptğ‘2\displaystyle\mathrm{dist}(\mathbf{R}_{1},\mathbf{R}_{2}) =cosâˆ’1â¡(12â€‹(trâ€‹(ğ‘1â€‹ğ‘2T)âˆ’1))absentsuperscript112trsubscriptğ‘1superscriptsubscriptğ‘2ğ‘‡1\displaystyle=\cos^{-1}\left(\tfrac{1}{2}(\textrm{tr}(\mathbf{R}_{1}\mathbf{R}_{2}^{T})-1)\right) (2)

where trâ€‹(â‹…)trâ‹…\textrm{tr}(\cdot) denotes the trace operation. Later in the paper, we consider the distance between two pairs of exponential coordinates, distâ€‹(ğ¬1,ğ¬2)distsubscriptğ¬1subscriptğ¬2\mathrm{dist}(\mathbf{s}_{1},\mathbf{s}_{2}), in (16), and the distance between two quaternions, distâ€‹(ğª1,ğª2)distsubscriptğª1subscriptğª2\mathrm{dist}(\mathbf{q}_{1},\mathbf{q}_{2}), in (45).

3 Lipschitz constants and measures of sensitivity for pose estimation neural networks

In this section, we will consider measuring the sensitivity of a pose estimation network, which can be thought of as a mathematical function which inputs a camera image (or similar structure) and outputs a rotation parameterization. Our analysis requires several tools which we will now define: metrics, pseudometrics, and Lipschitz constants.

3.1 Lipschitz constants

We start by defining metrics and pseudometrics [16, Ch.Â 4], which will be used to define Lipschitz constants.

Lipschitz constants are a tool to quantify the sensitivity of mathematical functions, and are one of the main tools used to analyze the sensitivity of neural networks. Given a function, ğŸğŸ\mathbf{f}, the Lipschitz constant describes the maximum amount the output of the function can change with respect to changes in the input [17, Ch.Â 9]. Lipschitz constants are useful due to their applicability to a wide array of functions, including vector-valued, nonlinear, and non-differentiable functions.

(3)

3.2 Euclidean Lipschitz constants

In this paper, we are interested in the case in which the function ğŸğŸ\mathbf{f} is a neural network that maps an image or other type of input to a rotation parameter. We can write this function as ğŸ:â„nâ†’ğ’«:ğŸâ†’superscriptâ„ğ‘›ğ’«\mathbf{f}:\mathbb{R}^{n}\to\mathcal{P}. Lipschitz constants are typically applied to neural networks using the metrics induced by the 1-, 2-, and âˆ\infty-norms for dğ’³subscriptğ‘‘ğ’³d_{\mathcal{X}} and dğ’´subscriptğ‘‘ğ’´d_{\mathcal{Y}}. We now present the Lipschitz constant in which both metrics are defined as the Euclidean distance.

Definition 4.

Consider a function ğŸ:â„nâ†’ğ’«:ğŸâ†’superscriptâ„ğ‘›ğ’«\mathbf{f}:\mathbb{R}^{n}\rightarrow\mathcal{P} which outputs a rotation parameter. The Euclidean Lipschitz constant, Lesubscriptğ¿ğ‘’L_{e}, of ğŸğŸ\mathbf{f} is the Lipschitz constant of the function using the Euclidean distance as the metric on both the input and output sets:

(5)

3.3 Rotational Lipschitz constants

Considering a neural network, ğŸğŸ\mathbf{f}, that maps an image to a rotation parameter, the Euclidean Lipschitz constant does not provide a meaningful measure of sensitivity due to the fact that the Euclidean distance between two rotation parameters is not a meaningful measure of rotational distance. So, to properly measure the sensitivity of these functions, we will create a Lipschitz constant that measures the distance between inputs using the Euclidean distance, and the distance between outputs using the rotational distance from Definition 1. We present this measure in the following definition.

Definition 5.

Consider a function ğŸ:â„nâ†’ğ’«:ğŸâ†’superscriptâ„ğ‘›ğ’«\mathbf{f}:\mathbb{R}^{n}\rightarrow\mathcal{P} that outputs a rotation parameter. The rotational Lipschitz constant, Lrsubscriptğ¿ğ‘ŸL_{r}, of ğŸğŸ\mathbf{f} is the Lipschitz constant of the function using the Euclidean distance as the metric on the input set, and the rotational distance as the metric on the output set:

Lrâ‰”supğ±1â‰ ğ±2distâ€‹(ğŸâ€‹(ğ±1),ğŸâ€‹(ğ±2))âˆ¥ğ±2âˆ’ğ±1âˆ¥.â‰”subscriptğ¿ğ‘Ÿsubscriptsupremumsubscriptğ±1subscriptğ±2distğŸsubscriptğ±1ğŸsubscriptğ±2delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ±2subscriptğ±1L_{r}\coloneqq\sup_{\mathbf{x}_{1}\neq\mathbf{x}_{2}}\frac{\mathrm{dist}(\mathbf{f}(\mathbf{x}_{1}),\mathbf{f}(\mathbf{x}_{2}))}{\lVert\mathbf{x}_{2}-\mathbf{x}_{1}\rVert}. (6)

We now note that the rotational distance function distâ€‹(â‹…,â‹…)distâ‹…â‹…\mathrm{dist}(\cdot,\cdot) from Definition 1 is a pseudometric and not a metric, which is due to the fact for some rotation parameterizations, distâ€‹(ğ©1,ğ©2)distsubscriptğ©1subscriptğ©2\mathrm{dist}(\mathbf{p}_{1},\mathbf{p}_{2}) may equal zero for some parameters ğ©1â‰ ğ©2subscriptğ©1subscriptğ©2\mathbf{p}_{1}{\neq}\mathbf{p}_{2}. As a result, the rotational Lipschitz constant Lrsubscriptğ¿ğ‘ŸL_{r} is not a true Lipschitz constant as described in Definition 3. However, this discrepancy is minor and does not have any negative effects on using the rotational Lipschitz constant to measure the sensitivity of a neural network.

As with Euclidean Lipschitz constants, it is too difficult to exactly calculate the rotational Lipschitz constant of complex functions such as neural networks, so instead we will derive an upper bound. This bound will require defining the following measure which relates the Euclidean and rotational distances between pairs of rotation parameters.

Definition 6.

Consider a rotation parameterization with set of parameters, ğ’«ğ’«\mathcal{P}. The distance ratio constant, Î¼ğœ‡\mu, of the parameterization is the maximum ratio of the rotational distance to the Euclidean distance over all pairs of parameters:

Î¼â‰”supğ©1,ğ©2âˆˆğ’«ğ©1â‰ ğ©2distâ€‹(ğ©1,ğ©2)âˆ¥ğ©2âˆ’ğ©1âˆ¥.â‰”ğœ‡subscriptsupremumsubscriptğ©1subscriptğ©2ğ’«subscriptğ©1subscriptğ©2distsubscriptğ©1subscriptğ©2delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ©2subscriptğ©1\mu\coloneqq\sup_{\begin{subarray}{c}\mathbf{p}_{1},\mathbf{p}_{2}\in\mathcal{P}\\ \mathbf{p}_{1}\neq\mathbf{p}_{2}\end{subarray}}\frac{\mathrm{dist}(\mathbf{p}_{1},\mathbf{p}_{2})}{\lVert\mathbf{p}_{2}-\mathbf{p}_{1}\rVert}. (7)

Note this definition is equivalent to applying the rotational Lipschitz constant from Definition 5 to the identity map ğŸâ€‹(ğ©)=ğ©ğŸğ©ğ©\mathbf{f}(\mathbf{p})=\mathbf{p}.

3.5 Application to pose estimation neural networks

The function, ğŸğŸ\mathbf{f}, that we have considered in this section will correspond to a feedforward pose estimation neural network. In order to apply the results from this section to such a network, there are several considerations we must make.

First, note that for networks which take RGB images as their inputs, the input, ğ±ğ±\mathbf{x}, will be a three-dimensional array. It is mathematically equivalent to consider such inputs to be vectors in â„nsuperscriptâ„ğ‘›\mathbb{R}^{n}. Also note that we have considered a function, ğŸğŸ\mathbf{f}, which outputs rotation parameters, but a pose estimation neural network will output pose, which consists of both position and rotation. However, pose is often represented as a concatenation of position and rotation, so in these cases we can split a network into position and rotation sub-networks, and consider each sub-network separately. Finally, as we noted before, the exact Euclidean Lipschitz constant, Lesubscriptğ¿ğ‘’L_{e}, is intractable to compute for all but very small toy networks, but an upper bound can be computed instead by taking the product of the individual bounds of the layers of the network.

In summary, we would like to compute a bound on the rotational Lipschitz constant from Theorem 7 for a pose estimation neural network. This bound is a function of two values: the Euclidean Lipschitz constant, Lesubscriptğ¿ğ‘’L_{e}, and the distance ratio constant, Î¼ğœ‡\mu. While we know how to compute an upper bound on Lesubscriptğ¿ğ‘’L_{e}, we are not aware of any work in which Î¼ğœ‡\mu is derived for any rotation parameterization. Accordingly, we will devote the next two sections of the paper to the derivation of Î¼ğœ‡\mu for two types of rotation parameterizations: exponential coordinates and quaternions.

Note that a common pose parameterization used in pose estimation networks is 2D projected points, in which pose is parameterized by a set of 2D points which represent 3D points on the object which have been projected into the image plane [1, 2, 4]. Unfortunately, for these types of parameterizations, the mapping between parameters and pose relies on Perspective-n-Point (PnP) algorithms, which often are solved via nonlinear optimization and also often rely on additional algorithms such as Random Sample Consensus (RANSAC). As a result, deriving closed-form sensitivity bounds for these parameterizations is intractable.

4 Exponential coordinates

In this section, we will derive the distance ratio constant from Definition 6 for exponential coordinates and unconstrained exponential coordinates.

4.1 Rotation parameterization

The first rotation parameterization we will consider is exponential coordinates. Although not commonly used in pose estimation neural networks, exponential coordinates are a fundamental and intuitive description of rotation used frequently in robotics applications. Additionally, as we will show later on, exponential coordinates have several properties which make them advantageous for developing pose estimation networks with provable sensitivity bounds.

Any 3D rotation can be described by a rotation of angle Î¸âˆˆâ„ğœƒâ„\theta\in\mathbb{R} about a unit-length axis ğâˆˆâ„3ğsuperscriptâ„3\mathbf{e}\in\mathbb{R}^{3}. Exponential coordinates, which we will denote as ğ¬âˆˆâ„3ğ¬superscriptâ„3\mathbf{s}\in\mathbb{R}^{3}, are simply the axis multiplied by the angle: ğ¬=Î¸â€‹ğâˆˆâ„3ğ¬ğœƒğsuperscriptâ„3\mathbf{s}=\theta\mathbf{e}\in\mathbb{R}^{3} [18, Ch.Â 3]. The term â€œexponentialâ€ comes from the fact that SO(3) is a Lie group, and exponential coordinates are a description of the Lie algebra of the Lie group, which can be mapped back to the group using the exponential map.

In general, exponential coordinates can be defined using any angle Î¸âˆˆ[0,âˆ)ğœƒ0\theta\in[0,\infty). We refer to the set of exponential coordinates defined with Î¸âˆˆ[0,âˆ)ğœƒ0\theta\in[0,\infty) as â€œunconstrainedâ€ exponential coordinates. However, exponential coordinates are typically defined with Î¸âˆˆ[0,Ï€]ğœƒ0ğœ‹\theta\in[0,\pi], which is the minimum set of angles that can describe all 3D rotations. This set of exponential coordinates corresponds to the three-dimensional ball of radius Ï€ğœ‹\pi, which we denote as â„¬Ï€subscriptâ„¬ğœ‹\mathcal{B}_{\pi}:

â„¬Ï€={ğ±âˆˆâ„3|âˆ¥ğ±âˆ¥â‰¤Ï€}.subscriptâ„¬ğœ‹conditional-setğ±superscriptâ„3delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥ğ±ğœ‹\displaystyle\mathcal{B}_{\pi}=\{\mathbf{x}\in\mathbb{R}^{3}~{}~{}|~{}~{}\lVert\mathbf{x}\rVert\leq\pi\}. (14)

There is a 1-to-1 mapping between points inside â„¬Ï€subscriptâ„¬ğœ‹\mathcal{B}_{\pi} and 3D rotations, and a 2-to-1 mapping between points on the surface â„¬Ï€subscriptâ„¬ğœ‹\mathcal{B}_{\pi} to 3D rotations. More specifically, antipodal points on the surface of the ball correspond to the same rotation (i.e., Ï€â€‹ğğœ‹ğ\pi\mathbf{e} and âˆ’Ï€â€‹ğğœ‹ğ-\pi\mathbf{e} correspond to the same rotation) [18, Ch.Â 3]. Note that while we could reduce the set â„¬Ï€subscriptâ„¬ğœ‹\mathcal{B}_{\pi} so that it is a 1-to-1 mapping, it would not change the results in this section.

We now consider how exponential coordinates can be composed. Let ğ¬1=Î¸1â€‹ğ1subscriptğ¬1subscriptğœƒ1subscriptğ1\mathbf{s}_{1}=\theta_{1}\mathbf{e}_{1} and ğ¬2=Î¸2â€‹ğ2subscriptğ¬2subscriptğœƒ2subscriptğ2\mathbf{s}_{2}=\theta_{2}\mathbf{e}_{2} denote two sets of exponential coordinates, and let ğ¬3=Î¸3â€‹ğ3subscriptğ¬3subscriptğœƒ3subscriptğ3\mathbf{s}_{3}=\theta_{3}\mathbf{e}_{3} denote the coordinates of the composite rotation of ğ¬1subscriptğ¬1\mathbf{s}_{1} and ğ¬2subscriptğ¬2\mathbf{s}_{2}. The angle Î¸3subscriptğœƒ3\theta_{3} can be determined using the following formula [19]:

cosâ¡Î¸32=cosâ¡Î¸12â€‹cosâ¡Î¸22âˆ’ğ1â‹…ğ2â€‹sinâ¡Î¸12â€‹sinâ¡Î¸22.subscriptğœƒ32subscriptğœƒ12subscriptğœƒ22â‹…subscriptğ1subscriptğ2subscriptğœƒ12subscriptğœƒ22\displaystyle\cos\tfrac{\theta_{3}}{2}=\cos\tfrac{\theta_{1}}{2}\cos\tfrac{\theta_{2}}{2}-\mathbf{e}_{1}\cdot\mathbf{e}_{2}\sin\tfrac{\theta_{1}}{2}\sin\tfrac{\theta_{2}}{2}. (15)

4.3 Planar analysis

To determine the distance ratio constant of exponential coordinates from Definition 6, we would need to optimize over all possible pairs of exponential coordinates, where each pair consists of the six degrees of freedom in ğ¬1subscriptğ¬1\mathbf{s}_{1} and ğ¬2subscriptğ¬2\mathbf{s}_{2}, and the two constraints âˆ¥ğ¬1âˆ¥â‰¤Ï€delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ¬1ğœ‹\lVert\mathbf{s}_{1}\rVert\leq\pi and âˆ¥ğ¬2âˆ¥â‰¤Ï€delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ¬2ğœ‹\lVert\mathbf{s}_{2}\rVert\leq\pi. The number of dimensions and constraints in this analysis is challenging, but we can analyze this problem in the plane defined by ğ¬1subscriptğ¬1\mathbf{s}_{1} and ğ¬2subscriptğ¬2\mathbf{s}_{2}, which reduces the number of variables and simplifies the analysis.

4.4 Distance ratio constants

We now approach the problem of analytically determining the distance ratio constant for exponential coordinates. Theorem 13.

Lemma 11 states that the distance ratio constant of exponential coordinates with angles Î¸âˆˆ[0,2â€‹Ï€]ğœƒ02ğœ‹\theta\in[0,2\pi] is one. Exponential coordinates with angles Î¸âˆˆ[0,Ï€]ğœƒ0ğœ‹\theta\in[0,\pi] are a subset of those exponential coordinates, and therefore the distance ratio constant of exponential coordinates with angles Î¸âˆˆ[0,Ï€]ğœƒ0ğœ‹\theta\in[0,\pi] is upper bounded by one. Furthermore, this upper bound is achieved in a few ways, one of which being when Î¸1âˆˆ(0,Ï€]subscriptğœƒ10ğœ‹\theta_{1}\in(0,\pi] and Î¸2=0subscriptğœƒ20\theta_{2}=0, in which case both distâ€‹(ğ¬1,ğ¬2)distsubscriptğ¬1subscriptğ¬2\mathrm{dist}(\mathbf{s}_{1},\mathbf{s}_{2}) and âˆ¥ğ¬2âˆ’ğ¬1âˆ¥delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ¬2subscriptğ¬1\lVert\mathbf{s}_{2}-\mathbf{s}_{1}\rVert equal Î¸1subscriptğœƒ1\theta_{1}. â–¡â–¡\square

5 Quaternions

In this section, we will derive the distance ratio constant from Definition 6 for quaternions and unconstrained quaternions.

5.1 Rotation parameterization

Quaternions are a common representation of rotation which can be derived from an axis-angle representation. Considering an angle, Î¸âˆˆâ„ğœƒâ„\theta\in\mathbb{R}, and unit-length axis, ğâˆˆâ„3ğsuperscriptâ„3\mathbf{e}\in\mathbb{R}^{3}, a quaternion can be written as [18, App.Â A]

ğª=[cosâ¡Î¸2ğâ€‹sinâ¡Î¸2]âˆˆâ„4.ğªmatrixğœƒ2ğğœƒ2superscriptâ„4\mathbf{q}=\begin{bmatrix}\cos\tfrac{\theta}{2}\\ \mathbf{e}\sin\tfrac{\theta}{2}\end{bmatrix}\in\mathbb{R}^{4}. (43)

The set of all possible quaternions corresponds to all 4D vectors with unit norm, which is equivalent to all points on the 3-sphere, ğ’®3âŠ‚â„4superscriptğ’®3superscriptâ„4\mathcal{S}^{3}\subset\mathbb{R}^{4}:

ğ’®3={ğ±âˆˆâ„4|âˆ¥ğ±âˆ¥=1}.superscriptğ’®3conditional-setğ±superscriptâ„4delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥ğ±1\displaystyle\mathcal{S}^{3}=\{\mathbf{x}\in\mathbb{R}^{4}~{}~{}|~{}~{}\lVert\mathbf{x}\rVert=1\}. (44)

Of particular relevance for the work here, quaternions are a double-covering of all possible 3D rotations, i.e., there are two quaternions that correspond to every 3D rotation. More specifically, every pair of antipodal quaternions represent the same rotation, which can be seen mathematically in (43) by taking quaternion ğªğª\mathbf{q} with angle Î¸ğœƒ\theta, and replacing Î¸ğœƒ\theta with the equivalent angle Î¸+2â€‹Ï€ğœƒ2ğœ‹\theta+2\pi. Note that while we could reduce the set ğ’®3subscriptğ’®3\mathcal{S}_{3} so that it is a 1-to-1 mapping, it would not change the results in this section.

Another version of quaternions we will consider are unconstrained quaternions, which are constructed by eliminating the unit-length constraint of quaternions, thereby allowing any vector in â„4superscriptâ„4\mathbb{R}^{4} to be associated with a 3D rotation after normalization into a unit quaternion. Unconstrained quaternions are advantageous as they allow a neural network to output any 4D vector as a valid parameterization of rotation. We will consider unconstrained quaternions in Section 5.5.

5.2 Rotational distance

We can derive the rotational distance between two quaternions using the equation for the rotational distance of exponential coordinates in Proposition 9, which is written as a function of axis ğğ\mathbf{e} and angle Î¸ğœƒ\theta.

Proposition 14.

The rotational distance between quaternions ğª1,ğª2âˆˆğ’®3subscriptğª1subscriptğª2superscriptğ’®3\mathbf{q}_{1},\mathbf{q}_{2}\in\mathcal{S}^{3} is given by:

distâ€‹(ğª1,ğª2)=2â€‹cosâˆ’1â¡(|ğª1â‹…ğª2|).distsubscriptğª1subscriptğª22superscript1â‹…subscriptğª1subscriptğª2\mathrm{dist}(\mathbf{q}_{1},\mathbf{q}_{2})=2\cos^{-1}(\lvert\mathbf{q}_{1}\cdot\mathbf{q}_{2}\rvert). (45)
{pf}

Using (43), we can write the quaternion vectors as

ğª1=[cosâ¡Î¸12ğ1â€‹sinâ¡Î¸12],ğª2=[cosâ¡Î¸22ğ2â€‹sinâ¡Î¸22].formulae-sequencesubscriptğª1matrixsubscriptğœƒ12subscriptğ1subscriptğœƒ12subscriptğª2matrixsubscriptğœƒ22subscriptğ2subscriptğœƒ22\displaystyle\mathbf{q}_{1}=\begin{bmatrix}\cos\tfrac{\theta_{1}}{2}\\ \mathbf{e}_{1}\sin\tfrac{\theta_{1}}{2}\end{bmatrix},~{}~{}~{}\mathbf{q}_{2}=\begin{bmatrix}\cos\tfrac{\theta_{2}}{2}\\ \mathbf{e}_{2}\sin\tfrac{\theta_{2}}{2}\end{bmatrix}. (46)

Taking the dot product of ğª1subscriptğª1\mathbf{q}_{1} and ğª2subscriptğª2\mathbf{q}_{2} yields

ğª1â‹…ğª2=cosâ¡Î¸12â€‹cosâ¡Î¸22+ğ1â‹…ğ2â€‹sinâ¡Î¸12â€‹sinâ¡Î¸22.â‹…subscriptğª1subscriptğª2absentsubscriptğœƒ12subscriptğœƒ22â‹…subscriptğ1subscriptğ2subscriptğœƒ12subscriptğœƒ22\displaystyle\begin{aligned} \mathbf{q}_{1}\cdot\mathbf{q}_{2}&=\cos\tfrac{\theta_{1}}{2}\cos\tfrac{\theta_{2}}{2}+\mathbf{e}_{1}\cdot\mathbf{e}_{2}\sin\tfrac{\theta_{1}}{2}\sin\tfrac{\theta_{2}}{2}.\end{aligned} (47)

The RHS of (47) is exactly the expression in the absolute value in (16), which is the equation for the rotational distance between axis-angle pairs (Î¸1subscriptğœƒ1\theta_{1},ğ1subscriptğ1\mathbf{e}_{1}) and (Î¸2subscriptğœƒ2\theta_{2},ğ2subscriptğ2\mathbf{e}_{2}). Since ğª1subscriptğª1\mathbf{q}_{1} and ğª2subscriptğª2\mathbf{q}_{2} correspond to the same 3D rotations as (Î¸1subscriptğœƒ1\theta_{1},ğ1subscriptğ1\mathbf{e}_{1}) and (Î¸2subscriptğœƒ2\theta_{2},ğ2subscriptğ2\mathbf{e}_{2}), respectively, plugging (47) into (16) yields (45). â–¡â–¡\square

We can also express the rotational distance between two quaternions as a function of the angle between their 4D quaternion vectors. This result will be used in Section 5.3.

Proposition 15.

Consider two quaternions ğª1,ğª2âˆˆğ’®3subscriptğª1subscriptğª2superscriptğ’®3\mathbf{q}_{1},\mathbf{q}_{2}\in\mathcal{S}^{3}, and let Ï•italic-Ï•\phi denote the angle between the 4D quaternion vectors. 5.3 Planar analysis

To determine the distance ratio constant of quaternions, we need to optimize over all possible pairs of quaternions, where each pair consists of the eight degrees of freedom in ğª1subscriptğª1\mathbf{q}_{1} and ğª2subscriptğª2\mathbf{q}_{2}, and the two constraints âˆ¥ğª1âˆ¥=1delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğª11\lVert\mathbf{q}_{1}\rVert=1 and âˆ¥ğª2âˆ¥=1delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğª21\lVert\mathbf{q}_{2}\rVert=1. The number of dimensions and constraints in this analysis is challenging, but we can analyze this problem in the plane defined by ğª1subscriptğª1\mathbf{q}_{1} and ğª2subscriptğª2\mathbf{q}_{2}, which reduces the number of variables and simplifies the analysis.

Lemma 16.

Consider two quaternions ğª1,ğª2âˆˆğ’®3subscriptğª1subscriptğª2superscriptğ’®3\mathbf{q}_{1},\mathbf{q}_{2}\in\mathcal{S}^{3}, and let cğ‘c denote their Euclidean distance. The ratio of the rotational distance and the Euclidean distance between the two quaternions is given by:

distâ€‹(ğª1,ğª2)âˆ¥ğª2âˆ’ğª1âˆ¥={4â€‹sinâˆ’1â¡(c2)/c,câˆˆ(0,2](2â€‹Ï€âˆ’4â€‹sinâˆ’1â¡(c2))/c,câˆˆ[2,2].distsubscriptğª1subscriptğª2delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğª2subscriptğª1cases4superscript1ğ‘2ğ‘ğ‘022ğœ‹4superscript1ğ‘2ğ‘ğ‘22\displaystyle\frac{\mathrm{dist}(\mathbf{q}_{1},\mathbf{q}_{2})}{\lVert\mathbf{q}_{2}-\mathbf{q}_{1}\rVert}=\begin{cases}4\sin^{-1}(\tfrac{c}{2})/c,&c\in(0,\sqrt{2}]\\ (2\pi-4\sin^{-1}(\tfrac{c}{2}))/c,&c\in[\sqrt{2},2].\end{cases} (52)
{pf}

We start by noting that any two quaternions define a plane, and hence we can analyze their relationship in that plane. A diagram is shown in Fig. 4. Since ğª1subscriptğª1\mathbf{q}_{1} and ğª2subscriptğª2\mathbf{q}_{2} lie on the unit circle, the distance between them can be interpreted as a chord length. Denoting this chord length as cğ‘c, we have

c=âˆ¥ğª2âˆ’ğª1âˆ¥.ğ‘delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğª2subscriptğª1c=\lVert\mathbf{q}_{2}-\mathbf{q}_{1}\rVert. (53)

Let Ï•italic-Ï•\phi denote the angle between the ğª1subscriptğª1\mathbf{q}_{1} vector and the ğª2subscriptğª2\mathbf{q}_{2} vector. We can relate the chord length cğ‘c, angle Ï•italic-Ï•\phi, and radius ÏğœŒ\rho using the trigonometric formula Ï•=2â€‹sinâˆ’1â¡(c2â€‹Ï)italic-Ï•2superscript1ğ‘2ğœŒ\phi=2\sin^{-1}(\tfrac{c}{2\rho}). Ï•=2â€‹sinâˆ’1â¡(c2).italic-Ï•2superscript1ğ‘2\displaystyle\phi=2\sin^{-1}(\tfrac{c}{2}). (54)

Plugging (54) into (48), and converting the intervals accordingly, yields

distâ€‹(ğª1,ğª2)={4â€‹sinâˆ’1â¡(c2),câˆˆ(0,2]2â€‹Ï€âˆ’4â€‹sinâˆ’1â¡(c2),câˆˆ[2,2].distsubscriptğª1subscriptğª2cases4superscript1ğ‘2ğ‘022ğœ‹4superscript1ğ‘2ğ‘22\mathrm{dist}(\mathbf{q}_{1},\mathbf{q}_{2})=\begin{cases}4\sin^{-1}(\tfrac{c}{2}),&c\in(0,\sqrt{2}]\\ 2\pi-4\sin^{-1}(\tfrac{c}{2}),&c\in[\sqrt{2},2].\end{cases} (55)

Plugging (55) and (53) into the LHS of (52) yields the RHS of (52). Note that in (52) we do not consider c=0ğ‘0c=0 as it corresponds to ğª1=ğª2subscriptğª1subscriptğª2\mathbf{q}_{1}=\mathbf{q}_{2}, which is not considered in the distance ratio constant from Definition 6. â–¡â–¡\square

5.4 Distance ratio constant

Next, we will derive the distance ratio constant. To facilitate the analysis, we will use the planar interpretation from Section 5.3.

Theorem 17.

The distance ratio constant, Î¼ğœ‡\mu, of quaternions ğª1subscriptğª1\mathbf{q}_{1} and ğª2subscriptğª2\mathbf{q}_{2} is:

Î¼=supğª1,ğª2âˆˆğ’®3ğª1â‰ ğª2distâ€‹(ğª1,ğª2)âˆ¥ğª2âˆ’ğª1âˆ¥=Ï€2.ğœ‡subscriptsupremumsubscriptğª1subscriptğª2superscriptğ’®3subscriptğª1subscriptğª2distsubscriptğª1subscriptğª2delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğª2subscriptğª1ğœ‹2\displaystyle\mu=\sup_{\begin{subarray}{c}\mathbf{q}_{1},\mathbf{q}_{2}\in\mathcal{S}^{3}\\ \mathbf{q}_{1}\neq\mathbf{q}_{2}\end{subarray}}\frac{\mathrm{dist}(\mathbf{q}_{1},\mathbf{q}_{2})}{\lVert\mathbf{q}_{2}-\mathbf{q}_{1}\rVert}=\frac{\pi}{\sqrt{2}}. (56)
{pf}

In Lemma 16 we showed that we can write the sensitivity of any two quaternions in terms of the single variable cğ‘c, which represents their Euclidean distance and chord length in the plane defined by the two quaternion vectors. Taking the derivative of (52) with respect to cğ‘c yields

ddâ€‹câ€‹distâ€‹(ğª1,ğª2)âˆ¥ğª2âˆ’ğª1âˆ¥={4c2â€‹(c4âˆ’c2âˆ’sinâˆ’1â¡(c2)),câˆˆ(0,2]âˆ’4c2â€‹(c4âˆ’c2+cosâˆ’1â¡(c2)),câˆˆ[2,2].ğ‘‘ğ‘‘ğ‘distsubscriptğª1subscriptğª2delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğª2subscriptğª1cases4superscriptğ‘2ğ‘4superscriptğ‘2superscript1ğ‘2ğ‘024superscriptğ‘2ğ‘4superscriptğ‘2superscript1ğ‘2ğ‘22\displaystyle\frac{d}{dc}\frac{\mathrm{dist}(\mathbf{q}_{1},\mathbf{q}_{2})}{\lVert\mathbf{q}_{2}-\mathbf{q}_{1}\rVert}{=}\begin{cases}\frac{4}{c^{2}}\left(\frac{c}{\sqrt{4-c^{2}}}-\sin^{-1}(\tfrac{c}{2})\right),&c\in(0,\sqrt{2}]\\ \frac{-4}{c^{2}}\left(\frac{c}{\sqrt{4-c^{2}}}+\cos^{-1}(\tfrac{c}{2})\right),&c\in[\sqrt{2},2].\end{cases} (57)

To begin, consider the first case of (57), where câˆˆ(0,2]ğ‘02c\in(0,\sqrt{2}]. The second term can be rearranged as follows:

c4âˆ’c2âˆ’sinâˆ’1â¡(c2)=(c2)/(1âˆ’(c2))2âˆ’sinâˆ’1â¡(c2)=tanâ¡(sinâˆ’1â¡(c2))âˆ’sinâˆ’1â¡(c2)ğ‘4superscriptğ‘2superscript1ğ‘2absentğ‘2superscript1ğ‘22superscript1ğ‘2missing-subexpressionabsentsuperscript1ğ‘2superscript1ğ‘2\displaystyle\begin{aligned} \frac{c}{\sqrt{4-c^{2}}}-\sin^{-1}(\tfrac{c}{2})&=(\tfrac{c}{2})/\sqrt{(1-(\tfrac{c}{2}))^{2}}-\sin^{-1}(\tfrac{c}{2})\\ &=\tan(\sin^{-1}(\tfrac{c}{2}))-\sin^{-1}(\tfrac{c}{2})\end{aligned} (58)

where in the last step we used the identity tanâ¡(sinâˆ’1â¡x)=x/1âˆ’x2superscript1ğ‘¥ğ‘¥1superscriptğ‘¥2\tan(\sin^{-1}x)=x/\sqrt{1-x^{2}}. Note that c/2ğ‘2c/2 is positive, so sinâˆ’1â¡(c2)superscript1ğ‘2\sin^{-1}(\tfrac{c}{2}) is on the interval (0,Ï€/2]0ğœ‹2(0,\pi/2]. Because tanâ¡x>xğ‘¥ğ‘¥\tan x>x for xâˆˆ(0,Ï€/2]ğ‘¥0ğœ‹2x\in(0,\pi/2], the bottom equation in (58) is positive, which since c>0ğ‘0c>0, implies that (57) is positive in the case of câˆˆ(0,2]ğ‘02c\in(0,\sqrt{2}].

Next, consider the second case of (57), where câˆˆ[2,2]ğ‘22c\in[\sqrt{2},2]. Restricting the interval to [2,2)22[\sqrt{2},2), the second term consists of the sum of two non-negative terms, which is non-negative. Since âˆ’4/c24superscriptğ‘2-4/c^{2} is negative, (57) is non-positive in the case of câˆˆ[2,2)ğ‘22c\in[\sqrt{2},2).

In summary, the derivative of (52) with respect to cğ‘c is positive for câˆˆ(0,2]ğ‘02c\in(0,\sqrt{2}] and non-positive for câˆˆ[2,2)ğ‘22c\in[\sqrt{2},2), so (52) is maximized at c=2ğ‘2c=\sqrt{2} on the interval câˆˆ(0,2)ğ‘02c\in(0,2). Evaluating (52) with c=2ğ‘2c=\sqrt{2} yields Ï€/2ğœ‹2\pi/\sqrt{2}. As (52) equals zero when c=2ğ‘2c=2, it has a maximum value of Ï€/2ğœ‹2\pi/\sqrt{2} on the interval (0,2]02(0,2]. â–¡â–¡\square

5.5 Unconstrained quaternions

We now consider unconstrained quaternions, which as we mentioned in Section 5.1, are constructed by eliminating the unit-length constraint of quaternions, thereby allowing any vector in â„4superscriptâ„4\mathbb{R}^{4} to be associated with a 3D rotation after normalization into a unit quaternion. We now derive the distance ratio constant of unconstrained quaternions.

Theorem 18.

The distance ratio constant, Î¼ğœ‡\mu, of unconstrained quaternions ğª1subscriptğª1\mathbf{q}_{1} and ğª2subscriptğª2\mathbf{q}_{2} is:

(59)
{pf}

â–¡â–¡\square

6 Construction of a pose estimation network with provable sensitivity bounds

In the previous two sections, we derived the distance ratio constant for several rotation parameterizations. In this section, we will consider the task of using these results along with Theorem 7 to design a pose estimation network with provable sensitivity bounds. We will show that unconstrained exponential coordinates are the only rotation parameterization we have considered which can accomplish this task. We will then design and train a pose estimation network using unconstrained exponential coordinates, and compute sensitivity bounds for it.

6.1 Summary of rotation parameterizations

In summary, we have derived the distance ratio constant for exponential coordinates and quaternions, as well as unconstrained versions of both of these parameterizations. The results are summarized in Fig. 5.

We also verified these results to be accurate by randomly sampling 107superscript10710^{7} pairs of 3D rotations and calculating the argument of the distance ratio constant for each pair.

We now consider the task of constructing a pose estimation network using each of these parameterizations, and calculating the rotational Lipschitz constant for each network. Unfortunately, this task is unrealizable for most of these parameterizations. Using exponential coordinates would require that the neural network only output vectors with magnitude less than or equal to Ï€ğœ‹\pi, which is not straightforward to accomplish. Similarly, using quaternions would require the neural network to only output vectors with unit magnitude. This unit magnitude constraint could be enforced using a unit-normalization function, but as we showed in Proposition 19, the unit-normalization function has an infinite Lipschitz constant. Similarly, unconstrained quaternions have an unbounded distance ratio constant.

However, unconstrained exponential coordinates do not have any of these challenges as they associate any vector in â„3superscriptâ„3\mathbb{R}^{3} with a valid 3D rotation, and they have a bounded distance ratio constant. As a result, it is possible to build a pose estimation neural network which outputs rotation in the form of an unconstrained three-dimensional vector, and then determine a bound on the networkâ€™s rotational Lipschitz constant using Theorem 7.

6.2 A pose estimation network with provable sensitivity bounds

In this section, we will design and train a neural network which outputs rotation in the form of unconstrained exponential coordinates, and then calculate a bound on its rotational Lipschitz constant. Our network outputs six-dimensional vectors, in which the first three states represent position and the last three states represent unconstrained exponential coordinates.

We constructed a feedforward network with rectified linear unit (ReLU) activation functions, which has a similar architecture to the original AlexNet [20]. The network architecture is shown in Fig. 6.

We consider our object of interest to be the â€œsoup canâ€ object from the YCB data set. We generated each image in the training and test data by generating renderings of the soup can at random poses using the computer graphics program Blender, and then superimposing the rendering on a random background image. Our training data consisted of 200,000 renderings superimposed on random background images from the SUN397 dataset. Our test data consisted of 10,000 renderings superimposed on background images from the 2017 COCO dataset. Each image was of size 3Ã—256Ã—25632562563{\times}256{\times}256, and sample images are shown in Fig. 7.

We created the cost function for the network as follows. Let ğ³iâˆˆâ„3subscriptğ³ğ‘–superscriptâ„3\mathbf{z}_{i}\in\mathbb{R}^{3} and ğ³^iâˆˆâ„3subscript^ğ³ğ‘–superscriptâ„3\hat{\mathbf{z}}_{i}\in\mathbb{R}^{3} denote the true and estimated position for the itâ€‹hsuperscriptğ‘–ğ‘¡â„i^{th} data point, respectively. Let ğ¬iâˆˆâ„¬Ï€subscriptğ¬ğ‘–subscriptâ„¬ğœ‹\mathbf{s}_{i}\in\mathcal{B}_{\pi} denote the true exponential coordinates, and ğ¬^iâˆˆâ„3subscript^ğ¬ğ‘–superscriptâ„3\hat{\mathbf{s}}_{i}\in\mathbb{R}^{3} denote the estimated unconstrained coordinates for the itâ€‹hsuperscriptğ‘–ğ‘¡â„i^{th} data point. Letting mğ‘šm denote the number of data points, we used the following cost function:

cost=âˆ‘i=1mâˆ¥ğ³iâˆ’ğ³^iâˆ¥2+distâ€‹(ğ¬i,ğ¬^i)costsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘šsuperscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ³ğ‘–subscript^ğ³ğ‘–2distsubscriptğ¬ğ‘–subscript^ğ¬ğ‘–\textrm{cost}=\sum_{i=1}^{m}\lVert\mathbf{z}_{i}-\hat{\mathbf{z}}_{i}\rVert^{2}+\mathrm{dist}(\mathbf{s}_{i},\hat{\mathbf{s}}_{i}) (65)

where distâ€‹(â‹…,â‹…)distâ‹…â‹…\mathrm{dist}(\cdot,\cdot) is the rotational distance equation from (16).

We trained the network using the Adadelta optimization algorithm with an initial learning rate of 10âˆ’1superscript10110^{-1}, and reduced the learning rate to 10âˆ’2superscript10210^{-2} when the error plateaued. We trained the network for 235 epochs, which resulted in average test sample rotation and position errors of 13Â°Â°\degree and 7cm, respectively. Note that about 1% of the networkâ€™s exponential coordinate estimates had a norm larger than Ï€ğœ‹\pi (i.e., were outside of the set â„¬Ï€subscriptâ„¬ğœ‹\mathcal{B}_{\pi}) for both training and test data.

The network outputs a six-dimensional vector which represents position and exponential coordinates. In order to analyze the position and rotation portions of the network independently, we split the network into two sub-networks by splitting the final fully-connected layer into two parts. We determined upper bounds on the Euclidean Lipschitz constants of the position and rotation sub-networks to be 13Ã—10913superscript10913\times 10^{9} and 84Ã—10984superscript10984\times 10^{9}, respectively. Using the latter value along with Theorems 7 and 12, we determined the following upper bound on the rotational Lipschitz constant of the network:

Lrâ‰¤84Ã—109.subscriptğ¿ğ‘Ÿ84superscript109\displaystyle L_{r}\leq 84\times 10^{9}. (66)

Note that all of our computed Lipschitz bounds are very large, but are of similar magnitude to classification networks with comparable architectures.

Finally, we can use Corollary 8 to determine a bound on the rotational change of the output, given a bound on input perturbations. Using (12), we can determine that if the Euclidean distance of two inputs is less than or equal to Ïµ=1.1Ã—10âˆ’11italic-Ïµ1.1superscript1011\epsilon=1.1\times 10^{-11}, then the rotational distance between the outputs will be less than or equal to 1 radian. We could also determine this bound for different values of Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon.

7 Conclusion

In this paper, we approached the task of deriving sensitivity bounds for pose estimation neural networks. We created a sensitivity measure that is a type of Lipschitz constant which measures the maximum rotational distance between two outputs of a network with respect to the Euclidean distance between the corresponding inputs. We then showed how a bound on this measure can be calculated from the Euclidean Lipschitz constant of the network and the distance ratio constant of the rotation parameterization. We derived the distance ratio constant for various rotation parameterizations, and discussed why most of these parameterizations, except for unconstrained exponential coordinates, make it difficult to compute a network-wide bound. We then constructed a neural network which outputs pose as a concatenation of position and unconstrained exponential coordinates, and calculated a bound on the rotational Lipschitz constant of the network.

There are several useful directions of future work we can consider. One is to further analyze 2D projection parameterizations. These parameterizations have shown to be very effective when used in pose estimation neural networks, and are also versatile due to the fact that these networks can be applied to images with a variety of camera intrinsics.

Finally, we again note that our sensitivity bounds were very large, but are of comparable magnitude to sensitivity bounds for classification networks. The high sensitivity of these bounds is a direct result of the bound on the Euclidean Lipschitz constant of the network being large. Therefore, in order to decrease our bounds and make them more practical, it is important to develop a way to calculate tighter bounds on the Euclidean Lipschitz constant of a network, or to constrain the Euclidean Lipschitz constant of the network during training. Note that both of these topics are actively being researched and have wide-ranging applicability in the field of deep learning.
